text: Bottle; pours cloudy copper with a beige head; floral aroma with citrus and caramel notes; taste is light bitter with caramel, citrus, and floral notes; dry, bitter finish with some lingering floral notes

Bottled, 355ml from Wine Lord in Hockley Birmingham. Hazy orange gold with white head. There is a fruity, orange hopped nose to this on pouring which translates into the beer itself. Hoppy and lightly bittering, just a hint of resin, some tropical fruit but mostly citrus notes. Easy on the palate. Enjoyable.
Bottle. Orangey Gold in colour. Hoppy; grassy and oily resinous hops, some pine. Fruity; grapefruit citrus. Malty backbone. Nice hoppy/fruity/malty balance. Very drinkable. (2011-03-13)

Golden, hazy, low lingering head. Aroma tofee, soapy. Palate heavy, oily. Medium carbonation. Taste balanced, malty notes, slight toffee and breadcrumbs. Actually I quite enjoy lack of hopiness. Bottle from 2014, aged hop character.
Minnesota Beer Trip #243. Slightly hazy amber, large creamy off-white head, good retention. Aroma of toasted malt, grain, mild citrus. The taste is grainy malt and citrus. Medium bodied.

Draft at a small restaurant in the middle of nowhere, Colorado. Poured a clear golden color, with a small white head. Aroma was nice, light citrus notes. Floral hop character. Flavor had pine, citrus. Pretty tasty.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a cloudy orange with small off white head that lasts. The aroma is grass and earthy hop. Medium body, citrus, caramel, light resin finish, good.
Pours a clear gold with light carbonation and white head. A malty and grainy aroma. A faint taste thats water down of citrus, malts and grains. A sweet citrus and dey grain aftertaste.

Nice earthy hops with a hint of pine in the aroma. I thought the scent would be stronger, hoppier. Good looking dark golden color with a very sticky bright white cloud of foam. Tastes malty and smooth with some hops in the aftertaste. Perfectly accentuates the difference between a pale ale and an IPA. Very drinkable; I could have several in one sitting. Good solid palate. This deserves to be a top 50 pale ale.

The aroma is light hops, citrus. Pours a clear light copper/orange, with white head, mostly lasting and excellent lacing. The taste is bitter. The body is medium/light, the texture creamy, the carbonation lively and the finish bitter. I think a very good beer.
Poured from brother-in-laws growler which makes it even better. Not the best Odell I have had but works well today.

12 oz bottle. Clear gold with a medium white head. Aroma of pine and citrus. Taste--the hop profile featured pine and grapefruit and reminded me a lot of SNPA, but the malt base was much sweeter with a dose of caramel. The palate was full and crisp. Finished short and sweet. Overall: A decent pale ale.

12 oz. bottle from Zach. Dark, hazy orange color, with a medium, bubbly, white head. Nose is caramel, grapefruit, butter toffee, chalk, and some resin. Fairly sweet, with a good bitterness. Medium to heavy body, sticky, and a bit astringent. This is a solid, malty, and pretty aggressive pale ale. Very creamy and thick.
From a 12 oz bottle. Pours a clear gold with an off white head. Grassy nose. Flavors of pine and a hint of citrus. Crisp finish.

Bottle picked up the other day at the Co-op not quite sure why Ive walked past this one so many times, but Im glad to have finally tried it. The color is a flat orange color with a two-finger creamy beige cap. Aroma is bright with fruity hops and light malt. Good hop flavors, lightly sweet with a pretty decent bitterness. Soft bready malts. Good stuff, I would love to see it in cans for the summer outdoor excursions.

Cloudy copper in color with a thick light tan head. Aroma of citrus and some spruce. Some carmel maltiness in the flavor followed with light citrus hops. Aftertaste of light bitter pine. Crisp mouthfeel with some carbonation.

Bottle pours clear golden with a small white head. Aroma is somewhat hoppy, citrus/orange with green tea and floral notes. Flavor is a herbal, leafy English pale ale flavor with a touch of sweet malt. Medium bodied and fairly crisp. Decent, but not terribly memorable.

Bottled. Smell hints at tropical fruits but really mainly straight up and down pale and hops on the nose. First thing you get is a pleasing dryness - comes on like a rye beer. Not a great deal more to it than that. You get some fresh grapefruit at the back but more of a hint than full on flavour. Nice but not a keeper.

Have had a few various times. This rating is from a bottle, poured into a glass. Deep golden pour. Thick, foamy white head. Aroma of citrus and grass. Taste is floral, very lightly bitter, grassy, some orange marmalade. Finish is sweet, lightly dry. Pretty refreshing and enjoyable. Solid, but nothing special.
12 oz. bottle. Pours dark amber with thick white head. Aroma was hops, citrus and pine. Taste was citrusy and lightly bitter.

Served on tap at the Pepsi Center. Golden brown color with a white head. Hops floral tropical fruit aroma. Light body. Malt floral mild hops and grapefruit flavor.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours pale to deep gold. Pine and citrus aroma. Slightly peppery. Very little malt flavor. Resiny hops. Bit of spice. Light body, thin mouthfeel. Watery. Lackluster pale ale.

Robe orangée, légèrement ambrée. Peu de mousse. Arômes de fruits confits et décorce dagrumes. Goût de céréales, biscuit, résine, agrumes. Final sur les agrumes. Plutôt courte en bouche. Texture légèrement huileuse, carbonatation fine.
Une bonne pale ale malheureusement sans profondeur.

Bottle from Cork & Cask. Hazy orange body with a thick off-white head. Thick lacing marks. Aroma of pot puri, shower gel and orange peel. Flavour of grapefruit, Earl Grey tea and sweet malts. Medium body with an oily texture. Soft fizz. Very tasty - Id love to try this on cask.

Tap @ Pinnacle Sports Bar: Pleasant creamy feel with a great hop but not too overpowering presence. This is one of those beers you could drink several of during a game - like I did while USC lost again.

Bottle 35,5cl / Botella 35,5cl.
@ Fresh Start Gas Station 149 North Sixth, Edgemont, SD, USA
A: Amber / Ambar.
T/S: Malt, caramel, slightly hoppy / Malta, caramelo, ligeramente a lupulo.

Von diesem Bier hatte ich mir ein etwas aromatischeren, hölzlichen Geschmack erhofft mit feinherben, spitzen Hopfennoten im Nachtrunk.. Das Bier weißt aber eher ein florales Aroma auf. In der Nase, ein blumiges, grasiges, leicht vanilliges Aroma mit einer dezenten scharfen Note. Im Antrunk eine sehr starke Rezenz, die in komplexe Hopfennoten übergehen. Etwas schwächerer Körper aber angenehmes Mundgefühl. Sehr schöne Haselnussfarbe. Schwache Schaumbildung. Angenehme, nachhängende Bittere. Interessantes, unerwartetes Bier.

Pours a dark golden color with white head. Nice floral hop aroma. Good flavor without being too bitter

Bottle. A solid pale ale, dark gold color, clear, light white head. Soft hop aroma with stronger bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2015 Pale ale from this classic Colorado brewery, pouring a clear, warm orange to almost amberish colour sustaining a big, frothy, rocky, thickly cobweb lacing, cream white head; adding the deposit leads to a warm cloudy amber robe. Inviting, fruity-hoppy aroma of orange peel, lots of fragrant field flowers, gooseberries, hint of roasted pine nuts, freshly cut grass and nettles (feeling a bit Belgian, actually), pleasantly meaty hint of chicken broth, pink grapefruit, green olives, toasted bread, tad lychee or melon from fruity hops. Clean, subduedly fruity onset, exotic touch but not overly so, hints of melon, lychee and kiwi, soft carbo, smooth, oily and slick mouthfeel, slick caramelly malt sweetishness, bit toasted, pleasant, leading to a finish of this malt sweetishness continuing but being countered with resiny, piney, fruity, citrussy hops, very aromatic retronasally with all those wonderful odours returning, as well as gently bittering, not harshly so, but in an English kind of way, providing some balance but allowing the smooth maltiness to finish it off, though the refined hoppiness, even leaving a kind of lime peel effect deep in the throat after swallowing, is obviously hard to ignore. Very agreeable beer, not boasting complexity or depth, but cleverly made with a perfect feeling for balance and not showing any flaws at all. Delightful on a summer afternoon and I would recommend this to anyone who wants to explore the regular pale ale style before (or after) venturing into the hoppier IPA culture. Though apparently labelled an EPA here, to me it still comes across more as an APA, but whatever the style, this is a lovely beer.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2015 Notes from recent Denver trip: Light orange pour, off white head, some lace. Nose is faint citrus. Lightly bitter. Middle is orange zest, light malt backbone. Finish is carbonation, sweet malt, mild hop bitterness. Well balanced offering.

Draft at Jack Quinns. Pours almost clear copper with a fizzy, bubbly beige head and some lacing. Tastes like caramel, dry orange and grapefruit hops, and sweet bready malt. Medium body and carbonation. Smells like orange, grapefruit, citrus hops, caramel, and sweet bready malt.

An orange beer, a head is medium and blond. Aroma has caramel malts, citrusfruits, and some piney hops. Taste has caramel and even some toffeeish malts, quite sweet, the bitterness is too mild even thats drying the mouth, some pine. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Stronger and more aromatic hoppyness should be included with strong caramel. OK.
Draft. Hazy orange amber color, medium fluffy white head. Floral aroma. Taste has orange peel and caramel. OK.

ery tasty. Pretty savory sweet citrus even breaks through this insanely messy BBQ pork and spicy Mac n cheese. Dies a bit in the middle. Back at the bar after flight was cancelled. Birds in the propellers apparently. Sure. Nothing but straight answers from the United staff today. Peaches, caramel, rrgf.

Hazy amber. Medium tan head. Moderate lacing. Floral and pine hop nose with some caramel and canteloupe. Medium bodied, fairly high carbonation. Fresh bread, watermelon rind, some pepper, toffee, honey, nutty and roasty notes. Tasty brew.

12 oz. bb 07/03/15. Mostly clear amber with a small lunar scape of foam. Nose is honey, toast, citrus, and resin. Flavors of flowery citrus, caramel, resin and a touch of melon appear in a good proportion. Light medium body is way too fizzy but has a nice balance.
Rated based on notes taken 13 Apr 2012 -- I really really enjoyed this beer. At IFS, Pueblo.

On tap at Mellow Mushroom. Pours a medium dark gold and makes a medium white head with great lacing. Smells of wheat and bread. Tastes of hops and hops and wheat. Very crisp. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12-oz. bottle. The nose features biscuity malts, toasted wheat bread, a balanced floral hoppy aroma with a touch of rosemary. Pours a light copper with with a thick creamy head and solid effervescence. A sharp bitter bite hits on the first sip but quickly mellows out, allowing a light caramel flavor to hold sway along with pine resin, prominent cereal grains, a touch of hay, and a minor (and surprising) rye-like spiciness. Despite the bitter start, the overall taste is well balanced. Likewise, the medium palate stays right down the middle with a slightly smooth texture and a moderate finish that concluded with a touch of bitterness. Whenever Im in the mood for a refreshing pale ale, I often return to this brew (particularly when its on nitro).
On draft. Cooper with one finger head. Floral hop aroma. Pine and floral taste. Easy to drink a few.

Sampled from a bottle at the Bull in Highgate. Copper colour with a white head. Lovely floral aromas. The taste is really delicately flavoured with hints of orange flowers, Turkish Delight and freshly-cut grass. Very pleasant and easy to drink. An interesting and original Pale Ale with great flavours.
Pours copper with a white head. Big floral hop aroma. Taste is bitter upfront with a dry finish.

Quite delicately hopped. Spicy with a notable floral aroma. I like it. So many bitters in England are desrcibed as having floral aromas but i generally get bread and stale flowers. This is sweet and fresh like rosewater. Well done.

Bottle. Clear copper gold withh a thin, frothy, off white head that lasts and laces. Aromas of lemon, caramel malt, spice and light pine. Flavor is the same. Medium bodied. Smooth with a slightly dry end.

Bottle. Mild floral hoppy aroma. Dry front hoppy notes. Mild bitterness. Reasonable hoppy beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from trembling madness in York. Not as good as their IN A but still very nice,

On tap from the Sherraton Hotel, Steamboat Springs, Co. Orange Amber with a white head and nice lacing. The aroma is hoppy, malty, not well defined, a bit caramelish. The taste is medium sweet, bitter finish. Pretty boring.

Nice hoppy floral aroma. Lovely hoppy taste and not too bitter. A very tasty beer - shame it's a small bottle. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice orange amber hue. Fresh clean citrusy hop aroma and flavor to match. A bit effervescent and bitter on the tongue so not incredibly sessionable but not bad either. Not very sweet but not sour.
Pours golden with a thin white head. A small aroma of hops but not much. A very very bitter taste.

(bottle) hazy amber colour with a frothy light-beige head. aroma of caramel and manure, quite resinous, with some notes of gooseberries, honeymolen and grapes. flavour is mostly grapes and caramel, slightly starchy, with a hint of talcum powder, some gently roasted malts and a light-bitter herbal-hoppy finish. medium-bodied with soft carbonation.
Bottle at home. Clear amber orange with a white head. Some floral notes. Light to medium body. Smooth. Pretty well balanced overall Id say.
Easy drinking pale ale. Doesnt stand out for me compared to some others but tastes good and goes does smooth.

Bottled import. Pours very hazy dark orange colour. Decent hop flavours and aroma, comes across much more hoppy than the 38 IBUs or whatever it says on the Odell website. Pleasant, pretty typical American Pale Ale (definitely not an English Pale Ale in any sense).

Bottle from Y Delyn Wine Bar, Mold. Pours hazy orange with a fluffy but quickly disappearing white head. Didnt really pick up much on the aroma; hops but not much else, slightly metallic too. Taste is much better - orangey zest, hoppy, with a nice balanced malt backbone. Overall, a pretty decent little beer; may re-rate at a later date as I was suffering with a little bit of a cold at the time of drinking!

Nice hoppy beer. Smells flowery, complex taste. 

Overall not a bad beer.

Tap at the Pure Bar and Kitchen, Birmingham. Poured a clear medium amber with a thin white head. The aroma is citrus nettle hop. The flavour is medium bitter witn a zesty citrus, woody, resin, hop bitter palate. Moderate to light bodied with average carbonation. A super session ale!
Leicht trübes orangegoldenes Bier mit ordentlcher stabiler beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr malzig, fruchtig, hopfig, bitter. Geschmack sehr hopfig, fruchtig, süß, etwas Gewürze, mild bitterer Abgang.
12 oz bottle. Pours amber orange, stiff white head. Aromas indistinct. Tastes smooth hops, bit o malt, well balanced.

Poured from bottle to glass. Honey hue with fizzy off white head that settled. Aroma is malt, resin, straw, slight sulphur. Mouthfeel is nice with a medium light body and crisp carbonation. Taste is dry sweet followed by a nice hop bitterness. Overall this is a decent brew.

Aroma: Medium-high hops, fruity, citrus, orange. Medium malt, biscuity.
Appearance: Body: Slightly hazy, copper. Head: Large, frothy head. Good retention.
Flavour: Medium-high bitterness. Medium-light sweetness. Dry finish with lingering bitterness. Medium hops flavours, fruity, orange. Light malt
Mouthfeel: Medium light body. Medium carbonation, creamy.
Overall: Very nice!

355 ml bottle, poured. Thanks Andre!

Tap at Drunken Monkey. Pours light orange with an inch of white foam. Leaves a fair amount of lacing. Has a bit of floral on the nose. Nice floral hip notes on the tongue. Finishes clean. This ones pretty solid.
A pretty light and usual beer. What you would expect in terms of hops and malts. Well balanced. Hoppy up front and at the finish with a smoother and sweeter middle.

Aroma has citrus and pine, with a bit of bready malt. Pours amber-orange with a decent off white foam head, with good retention and lacing. Taste is where this one lets down. Some hop bitterness leads the way along with muted citrus. Floral hops. Nothing too strong. Light bodied and thin. Overall not Odells best attempt, but not horrible.
smells of malt and barley and cigar smoke (odd that i couldnt smell any hops?) dark amber with white foamy head. Rich and smooth creamy aftertaste, reminds me of rodenbach grand cru. excellent.
Bottle. Pours hazy orange with thick white head. Aroma is very piney, citrusy, vanilla, fruity. Taste is well balance, piney, caramel. Solid.

355ml bottle from Appellation Wines, Cheers Ash! Pours clear amber, thin white head. Big pine and skunky hop aromas, light caramel. Taste is resinous bitter, orange, light malt. Good balance. Really nice beer.
(Backlog) Bottle at fantasy tasting at Pauls. Amber orange pour with white head. Herbal, spice, and lighter sweet tones.
Bottle from Glug Newcastle. Very hoppy in flavour but not overwhelmingly so. An enjoyably fruity, floral hint too
Light amber with thin white head. Aromas of toffee apples. Taste medium sweet, light bitter and trace of sourness. Sustained carbonation. Very drinkable if slightly bland.
Bottle at home. Pours copper amber, bit of apple on nose and toffee, taste is sweet, sugary, pine, a bit more green apple.

I guess one of the 10 half barrel kegs made it down to Austin. Smells like weed. Rich amber color. White head lo ses its lace and head one the way down. Flavors of bitterness, and flowers. Extra fizzy body its all that remains.
Bottles from Beers of Europe and Coppers, Newcastle. A hazy amber ale with a chewy orange marmalade flavour, slight burnt toffee notes and a silky smooth slight bitter finish. Superb!
Typical Odell ale. Great color has a nice smell but the taste is where its at. Great beer that keeps you wanting more.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; light clear copper pour with big fluffy magnolia head, tangerine and caramel aroma, taste has light pine with grapefruit a hint of sweet caramel, a hint of orange bitter finish very pleasant.
Draft - Nitro - Piney, grapefruit with an earthy finish. Clear gold with a great white head. Light earthy hops and an almost light sourness with the bitterness. If only tastes as good as it looked.

Pours a nice dark gold, hint of copper with some off white fizz. The aroma is pale cereal grains with a moderate hop character. The flavor is nice and smooth grains, smooth cereal and light biscuit with some light citrus and earthy floral hops along with a little fruity peach like flavor, all moderate throughout the beer. Pretty easy going and would bee a great session beer.
Impressively hoppy pale ale. Beautiful copper color. White medium head. Recommend to try this one

bottle. orange pour with a bit of sediment and a small white head. biscuit aroma with light citrus hop notes. med body, deep citrus tones throughout with nice supporting sweetness from the caramel malt and biscuit notes from the Munich malt. dry and sweet finish with lingering hop flavors.
tap. amber with small head. medium malt body with some caramel and citrus. substantial hops. i dig it.
Nice golden Amber color,very good head and nice pale ale aroma,a very good basic pale ale,will drink this one again

Bottle from StarmoreBoss, Sheffield. Lightly hazy, amber colour. Filmy, off white head. Privet leaf, wet hop, type aroma. Some light savouriness, too. Hint of caramel. Hint of bubblegum. Taste is grassy dry. Fruity sweetness underlies. Short, dry finish. Light sweetness right at the end.

Reviewed from notes.
The appearance has a slightly hazy orange brown body with a one finger white foamy head that dies within thirty seconds. There is a slight amount of carbonation is seen rising.
The smell has some light caramel, malts and bitter hops.
The taste is slightly sweet, caramel aftertaste, dry finish.
The palate is light and sessionable. Carbonation seems a bit higher than most English Pale Ales, but not overwhelming.
Overall, this is a pretty good EPA that I would probably have again.

Bottle from Zipps Liquors. Mild caramel nose with some grass. Orange/amber, smooth creamy head. Large caramel and then a big hit of rich hopping. Hint of tobacco. Smooth balanced finish. Medium body. This is one tasty pale ale, much more highly hopped than is normal for the style.

On tap at the Pepsi Center. Pour is clear orange-amber with a frothy white head and great lacing. Grapefruit peel, candied oranges, grassy, bready, caramelly, and marmalade in the aroma. Taste is grassy, doughy, bready, bitter fruit peel, caramel, and honey with a medium bitter finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Decent old school pale ale.

Aroma: massive floral, grassy hops. Appearance: medium dark clear brown, small to medium white frothy head. Taste: light sweet. Palate: hops all over again, hardly any bitterness though, relatively short finish, not unpleasant, but a bit underpowered. Overall: decent English Pale Ale, massive hop aroma, but palate could be more pronounced. Bottle from Beer Hawk, England.

Thin malts taste. Not much going on here. Very mild hops that don't stay with you. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330ml bottle from Nelsons Wine, Merton. Pours hazy amber with a decent head that dissipates gradually. Citrus aromas with undertones of caramel. Smooth finish on the palate and not too bitter. Nice beer,
Bottle at Stallyktan. Light hoppy and fruity smell. Bready malty, light hoppy aroma. Smooth mouthfeel and easy to drink.
decent english pale ale....pours golden...thin head...light lacing....citrusy ....super hoppy....a little better than average beer.

One of the better Pale ales I have had. Having it in steamboat near where r is made. Really smooth and easily crushable. Has a nice bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bought this for a friend. He gave one to me and this is it. Not a whole lot to say about this beer. Im not a fan of Pale Ales and this is no exception. Smells terribly hoppy, worse than grapefruit, more like weeds. If you like Pale Ales or even IPAs Im guessing you will like this. Not for me.
Definitely one of my favorites for the american pale ale category. Unique in the use of so many hop varieties but they all work together so well. Will pick this up again soon.
12 floz bottle from Beermoth, Manchester. Wondrously hoppy aroma, pours deep gold with bucketloads of finely tuned hops with a slight resinous quality and low-lying bitter finish. Tastes like an IPA.

February 5, 2014 - on tap at iTap. Clear golden with nice head and lacing. Citrus and piney hops in the aroma. Taste was nicely balanced with the hops and malt. Light to medium body with soft carbonation. Easy to drink and nice clean finish.

Bottle from a trade with Tsekouratos. Pours hazy golden with a big creamy white head. Aroma of flowery and orange hops, some peach. Taste is moderate sweet, weak honey malts,with a slightly dry end, citrussy hops.

Tap - good size foamy head, light copper flavor, earthy hop aroma and flavor, mild malt backbone, slightly dry finish, pretty good overall

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(draft @ Odell Brewing - Fort Collins, CO) Orange pour with a fizzy white head. Good amount of citrus in the aroma, which I definitely enjoy moreso than the overly bitter hop aroma. Pine resin and lots of citrus in the flavor with a clean and slightly fruity finish.
Cloudy deep orange body, thin foam head. Aroma of pine and some orange, earth. Same taste, medium body, medium to high carbonation. Very good beer.

Hazy amber pour with frothy off white head. Hop heavy spruce aroma but the toasted bread malt is easily identified. The taste is a complex symphony of multiple bitter yet refined hops playing tag with the sweet malt. Hop forward. This brew is a medium bodied pale ale with a drawn out finish. Odell, I heart you.

5 Barrel Pale Ale is a wonderful oddity. Its hoppy, sure, but it has a fruity sweetness that Ive not encountered in any other pale ale. The strong malt presence certainly helps, but the hops also help to create those notes of citrus, berry, and even tea. Odell did a great with this pale ale. Its something totally different in the wide, and often repetitive, world of hoppy beer.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle.

A- Citrus, floral, herbs, bread.

A- Copper color, cloudy liquid, white head.

T- Mild citrus, floral, doughy, tea.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, crisp finish.

O- A refreshing pale ale. Not too bitter, and very drinkable.

Bottle from Fyne Wines, Argyll. Dulled hop aromas with slight lemon zest. Very soft on the palate with gentle effervescence, subtle nuttiness and constant undertones of bittering hops. A very moreish Pale Ale despite delicacy of flavours.
Bottle @home, pours amber, malty sweetness on the nose. Fruity, lime citrus, floral as well on the palate, nice without being great.

(Bottle): Pours a hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma of citrus fruit, malt, bread and floral notes. Flavour is nice and malty at first then hits with a floral/grassy hop and citrus fruits. Sweet fruit, bread and slight caramel notes in the finish. Very Drinkable.
From the bottle, dark orange pour, white head, grassy, resiny and some minor citrus. Pretty tasty pale ale. Good stuff.

Pours a nice hazy orange with firmly suspended sediment and lasting soapy head. Aroma is bready malts, citrus, and a little tea, balanced nicely. Taste is much of the same, citrus into earthy, bready malts and a dry finish. Palate is medium bodied with high carbonation.

12oz bottle thanks to peterhazelton. Pours a hazy orange color with a finger of off white head. Aroma of oranges, citrus zest, bready malts, and tea. Taste is of citrus zest, bitter grapefruit, sweet grain, and black tea. Nice beer!
355ml bottle. hazy amber color with medium head and nice lacing. aroma of floral hops and caramel. taste of sweet malts and hoppy notes with dry finish. thin body.
Sampled at the brewery. This is a nitro pour. The aroma is floral and bready. The flavor is citrus, floral, fruity, grainy. Dry finish.

355ml bottle from Beer Hawk - Copper body, thick white top. Nose is tangerine, floral notes and other citrus. Palate is a gentle carbonation, with the taste a bit on the bitter-sweet side. Very enjoyable.

In bottle, pours copper-orange color. For all the hop stories on the making of the beer on the label, the hop aroma is surprisingly muted. Nice head and lasting lace. Medium-bodied, nicely balanced malt/hop middle, finishing crisp, clean and deftly carbonated.
bottle. copperish pour. bread, earthy, floral bitterness. some orange zest. medium mouthfeel. Solid pale

A mid orange coloured beer with a thick white head. A light, citrusy fruit hop aroma, orange and floral. Dry mouthfeel. A zesty citrus fruit taste, limes and oranges, floral hops and a touch of woody spice. Hoppy finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Yes. Yes. Yes. My fave of my beersploration so far. Great color, appearance, head, balance, aroma. Huzzah!
This is a pretty solid, well balanced ale. Biscuity, sweetish malt, with a citrus hop bite that is surprisingly understated.

Amber with a thin white head. Aroma is quite malty, some lemon, earthy hops. Taste is light sweet with a fairly well balanced, light sour and bitter finish. Oily texture, light carbonation. Quite nice.

12 oz bottle. Aroma is a skunky, bitter, wine-like aroma. Appearance is a dark bronze with a frothy, cream-colored head. Taste is hop bitter with a fruit like flavor in it. Palate is pretty clean. Overall, a decent pale ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle, poured a hazy golden color with minimal white head. Great taste, not overpowering on the hop department.
At Odell. Pours big soft nitro head. Golden orange. Aroma is barrel, light earth hops taste is big spicy earthy hops. Sticky hops. Light pine. Nice. Finish sweet pine and kinda quick pleasant.

On tap @ Odell. Amber pour with a white head. Strong bread and malt aromas. Very floral, some perfume, and orange zest. Light grass, pine, and biscuit. Flavor is slightly citric, some grass, and biscuit. Toast, bread, and caramel. Light bitterness, slight olive aftertaste.
Pours a medium orange with a white head. Slightly murky. Aroma of mostly malts. Not much hop aroma. Taste is similar. Crisp finish with a refreshing feel and medium light carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2013 Bottle Cotteridge Wines. Thoroughly disappointed. Took the plunge against the tides of discontent - Odells triumph that is their IPA led me here. Decent nose of mostly sweet fruit - apricot, peach maybe? 
Palate was poor - thin with almost a diluted feel. 
Taste - Really lacks nuance. The sweet citrus is bold but almost artificial tasting. Leaves a sugar coating feel on teeth - like cheap sweets. Very little malt.

Tap pour at 3 Squares in a less than pint glass. Crisp quality beer that would fit well in anyones stable of pale ales. Little lacing. Great aroma of hops that carries throughout the beer. Not much in terms of complexity but a solid option.
Tap. Copper, with white head and decent lacing. Piney aroma. Bitter hop crispness with good malt finish. Solid beer from a great brewery.
Pours a golden color with white head. Aromas of hoppy bitterness. This reminds me of a well balanced IPA. It has a little more hop presence up front and a mild malt backbone.
UPDATED: APR 20, 2014 12 oz Bottle. The beer pours to a dark golden color. The aroma was medium grassy hops & bread . The taste was light with a bitter sweet finish. Overall a good Pale Ale.

Bottle at the Beer Emporium, Bristol. Mid golden orange clolour, with a small slightly off white head. Nicely hopped aroma with mandarins and grapefruit. Medium sweet, medium bodied, average carbonation.
Bottle. Surprised I hadnt rated this previously. Pour is a hazy orange with white head. Decent hops, caramel, some citrus.

Doesn't really compare to the other pales I've had recently. Easily go with St Lupulin if you want an Odell's pale.

poured a copper orange with a small head.  sweet caramel and fruity nose, gives over to a too thin and oily mouth feel.  
keg.  blind jacks knaresborough.

Nitro tap at the Brewery. Pours with a hazed golden body and a nitro milky head. Aromas are fruity, biscuity, grainy at first with some esters at the finish. Flavors are grainy, oatmeal, cereal, medium bitter with light hops and esters. Medium dry with a lasting bitterness. Nitro carbonation (soft).
Light hazy amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and moderate hoppy - fruity. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter finish. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 221111
Bottle. Slightly hazy deep golden with small white head. Aroma is malt, hops and a little citrus. Flavour is malt, hops, caramel, citrus, fruit, grass and medium bitter.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are fresh hops, citrus, peach, flowers and malt.

Draft at Odell. Pours a deep gold verging on reddish with a stiff head. Nose is quite hop forward, citrus and pine resin. Fairly generic, but in a good way. Some soft biscuity malts come through as well. Clean. On tasting, nice level of bitterness balances out the malty level of this one. Nice and floral. Clean and decent, but not really too much of a standout. Crystal malt is in restraint, which is good.

Bottle shared by someone at the October Houston tasting. Pours a near clear gold with a white head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma has nice earthy grass and pine hops with a deep bread backing. Flavor is a bit sweeter but a decent amount of grass and pine hops.

A hazy rusty orange colored beer with a small off white head that is quick to dissipate.  The aroma is floral and fruity with some lemon and pine.  The flavor is not very strong but is floral and citrus and extremely smooth without much in the way of bitterness.  This beer would be perfect if it were a little more full bodied and full flavored.
Golden yellow/orange colour with little to no head. Smells unfresh hops, orange peel. Tastes bitter, fruity, sweet, toffee. Bit flat, medium body.
Nice not too aggressively hoppy Pale Ale. Pale Amber colour. A bit musty in the aroma. Drinks well, though not massively complex.

Surprised I havent rated this one yet. Great-looking red-orange pour with a very nice, sticky head. Average hop aroma with some citrus. Flavor is very malty with a stale finish. More like an amber than a pale.

Bottle @ Joes Tasting shared with Joes and Dutchdrebus. Slightly hazy orange color, almost no head. Smell hints of sour, old hops (a bit faint) and lightly musty. Taste lightly hops, bitter, fruity. Nice carbo, low to medium body. Note: Best before February 9th 2011.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Clear amber-gold with decent cream colored head and nice lacing for an EPA.

Aroma: Semi-sweet caramel, tea, spicy and citric hops.

Taste: Nicely balanced between malts and hops. The malts are loaded with caramel, tea and a mild earthiness, while the hops are fresh and spicy with twinge of citrus. Hoppier than a typical EPA, but it does not drown out the malts.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, medium body, nice drying finish. More crisp than a typical EPA but it suits the beer well.

Overall: One of the better English Pale Ales I have had, with a great balance, slightly ramped-up hops, and a nice feel overall.

In bottle at the Odell tasting at Appellation. A blonde ale with a thin white head. Hoppy aroma of pine, passion fruit, caramel and biscuity malt. Not overly bitter with flavours of pine, pineapple, passion fruit and caramel. A little thin with a foamy mouth-feel. Mild carbonation and CO2 prickle. OK.
Serve nitro draft at the brewery.  Amber with creamy light beige head.  Good balance of hops and malts.  Would also like to try the non-nitro version.

nice! just the right amount of hops for me (low)   head. Aroma of mellow herbal and earthy hops. Malty sweetnes with some smooth hop bitterness.  creamy mouth feel. 
 
Good session beer

12oz bottle. Hazy amber color. good white head. Aroma is very notable with strong floral hops and sweet bread. Tasted predominately of sweet malt with the very fruity hops. The hop flavor isnt bitter and floral like most american style pale ales
Copper orange pour with a nice white head. Smell is floral and citrusy. Flavor has a mild sweetness and finishes nice and hoppy with a little bitterness at the end. A nice pale ale.

Bottle, 31/07/11. Slightly veiled brass-gold with a fine lacing collar and marmalade floaties. Peach boiled sweets and Turkish delight aroma. Peach  Liptons iced tea flavour with some chalkiness, roses and more peach boiled sweets in the mix. Powdery orange Smartie sweetness, lemon icing notes. Not my kind of thing but the missus loved it.

stupid tv! be more funny!! .. . caramel on the pour, decent foam .. . bark and sap dominate .. . lacing is crazy .. . good stuff, fucked and crazy, but muhhhh .. . are you just holding on to the can??

Denver, Co. - Tower Liquors - 12 oz bottle. Medium copper pour, sticky off-white head that leaves plenty of lacing. Clean, light spruce aroma with a brief floral back end. Flavor is crisp with a hint of might citrus. Some nuttiness, faint fruitiness reminiscent of peaches. Crisp, refreshing mouthfeel. Great session material.
Bottle thanks to Victor. Pours light caramel/gold. Tan head. Nose/taste of sweet and pale malts, fuggles and hops. Medium body. Clean and crisp finish.

Bottle at Victors bracket box tasting at Pauls.  Pours a clear amber gold with a thin white head.  Big sticky citrus and malt.  Toast and malt, sweet toast and malt.  Crisp and clean, long slow grapefruit.

A bright amber beer with sticky resinous hop aroma with underlying peaches. Grapefruit dominant in the body alongside some pine needle followed by a bitter spike with a sweet but grapefruit pithy finish.
Bright orange and hazy with a small off-white head. Aroma isof light hops, citrus, slightly sweet and floral. Taste is of tropical fruits, light citrus and grain.
Clear look, orangish color, off whitish head.  The smell is citrus, fruits, apricots, peach, and hops. The taste is more hoppy, pleasant, clean, light bitterness, but goes down easy.

Poured a nice copper-amber color, with some decent cloudy white foam on top. Aromas of caramel, light brown sugar and some floral hops. On the palate, light bodied, with caramel, biscuit and a hint of hops.

Bottle looks simple, but really not boring. Beer in the glass zippy, small head. Hoppy-fresh aroma. Starts mild, fine spicy with a sweet touch. Finish more and more flowery-hoppy, reminds me of an IPA, modest sourish, fine grasy. Aftertaste not too dry, again with some sweet hints. A great beer!

Thanks to my wife for bringing it back from the states!
light and crisp not much here everything is becoming bland except for ipas and sours. on tap at odell

Thanks to Joel for this... a murky peach with a lot of orange, a light tan head ok ring... pretty boring nose, mostly sweet malts throughout, not bad, just blah... the taste is just blah too, malt with some bitter alcohol, hops dont really present at all, drinkable but so boring, why?... is this old or just not as hoppy as they think?

Bottle from Stirchley Wines and Spirits, Birmingham. Delicious sweet, lychee aroma and the same fruity notes from the hops when they run across my tastebuds. Gentle, spritzy flavour, but fully formed. Light, crisp, with an aftertaste and overall impression which is very tasty, without ever being massive. Im not sure what makes this an EPA rather than APA, as I immediately thought it was a typical example of the latter. Liked it. Easy to drink.

A well filtered beer that is golden copper.  A one finger off white head.  A fairly aggressive aroma of caramel and tart citrus.  The flavor begins with complex hop notes.  It offers fruit that includes tangerine, flowers, and some grapefruit.  Despite the complexity the hops are soft and gentle and some assertiveness would have been nice.  Caramel is also noted but is a bit thin.  A general sourness permeates.
355ml bottle.  Pours a hazy dark amber with a small head.  Aroma is orange hop balanced with some malt.  Taste is watery to start and has a watery orange finished.  Balanced but taste is faint.
Bottle. light Amber with a thin head. Aroma is quite light grape. Flavour is fruity with a citrus hop finish. Finish is very dry.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2016 Wapiti Pub. Clear golden orange with a puffy, lacing cream colored head. Aroma of pale malt, apricot and piney hops. Watery taste of pale malts and Some bitterness with a bit of fruit. Thin and boring.
Pours light copper with small white head.  Aroma of yeast and mash.  Nice bitterness the whole way through.  Med-full mouth feel. Lasting bitterness with a faint Lemon finish.

Aroma is that of slight peaches but mostly leather. Appearance is cloudy golden brown with a healthy off white head that sticks around.Taste is that of malt and slightly grassy hops. Palate is somewhat creamy and slightly carbonated. Medium to long finish. Overall I was expecting more from this particular beer- I like a lot of Odells beers.

Pours orangey amber. Good head. Nose is citrousy. Lemony and pine and bit of malt. Taste is nice kick of zingy citrous: grapefruit, lemon and orange. Nicely balanced with caramel malt on the back straight. Good well balamced beer. Liking Odells stuff.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a light amber color with an off white head, about two fingers to start out. A bit of light lacing. Nose brings some floral and citrus hops along with some light malt. Slight hoppy bitterness with some floral notes in the taste. Some light grain as well. Good feel with some mild bitterness. This is a pretty good example of the style and drinks fairly well.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-31-2010
Bottle @ Blackfriars. Hazy amber brown colour with a good foamy head. Sweet hoppy aroma. Jammy hoppy flavour with sweet aftertaste. Not bad.

12 oz. bottle at iTap-Soulard. Pours a slightly cloudy orange-gold color with a finger-thick eggshell white head that leaves some lace in the glass. Aroma of mixed malts (biscuits, crackers, toast), grassy hops, and just a pinch of citrus. Flavor of the same variety of malts, leafy hops, corn flakes, and minerals. Light-medium bodied, with medium carbonation and a leafy mouthfeel and crisp finish. Decent EPA.

21 March 2011, bottle, and probably colder than it should have been served. amber orange colour and hazy. lovely nose! sweet malt, some alcohol and nice pine hop and red fruit aroma. med body and moderately fizzy. so much on nose but taste is primarily nettle hops. some raising and malt but not as diverse as the nose.

Keg at the Euston Tap. Pours a cloudy amber, with a small off white head. Strong aromas, floral, honeycomb, toffee, sherbert, tang, slight hint of wheat, and a hint of apricot made for a quite complex aroma in a great beer.

(Draught at Odell) clear copper with creamy lasting head. Nose of crisp pale malt, grapefruity, orange, fresh citrus rind. Taste of pine, bitter grapefruit, and cracker. Smooth finish, biscuity linger, slick body, a bit old tasting and watery.

It poured a cloudy amber with a very nice white head. The aroma was very nice, with caramel, malt and a bit of citrus hops. The flavor was sweet caramel, malt and some citrus hops. This was a very good brew.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2014 Amber/orange in appearance. Honey, sultana and malt on the nose. The taste is honey and malt with a nettley finish. Maybe should be room temperature. Big structure, fairly creamy texture and zingy. Rich but balanced.
Pours a reddish amber color with a large canvas colored head. Notes of citrus, caramel, brown sugar, and sunflower. Great balance, crisp lasting finish. Nice.

12 bottle from Whole Foods in Tucson 
Appearance: Clear golden with a nice sized white head and some lacing 
Aroma:Citrus, woody and earthy 
Taste: Caramel, citrus and woody 
Decent. It sounds like a good idea, but not all good ideas are a good choice.
It sounded like it would be good, but was underwhelming. It is light and grainy with not a large amount of hops.

Bottle @ Hotelroom, Denver. Pours orange with a smal white head. Aroma of caramel and citruss. Taste sweet malt, caramel citruss and floral hops. Thin to medium body, medium carbonation. Refreshing on a sunny afternoon after work. 090311

Pours a cloudy orange, little to no head, strong aroma. Very smooth, very nice, I really like this. The bottle and label are also nice. This really is an amazingly smooth, yet quite hoppy Pale. Well done.

Bottle. Pours a clear bright orange, thin head. Aroma is prominent, citrus at the forefront. Flavor is pale malts, a bit of roast. Has a slight alkaline/chalk thing going on. Slightly sweet with a big fresh citrus hop kick at the back end. Solid.

Bottle from BoE. Slightly hazy orange with a white head. Sweet caramel aroma. I hoped the taste would carry similar notes, but frankly I thought it tasted of soap, lacking any nuance or subtlety. Mid bitter finish. Wasnt impressed.
Bottle, from a while back.  Color was orange to caramel with not much white head.  Aroma of caramel, bread and citrus.  Flavor of sweet malt, caramel, bread and earth.  Not much hops on hops, but ok.
A good pale ale.  Beautiful color, great aroma.  The flavor is well balanced, but seems slightly one-dimensional to me.  I like it.

Bottle - 15/1/11. Copper coloured beer. Malt, flowers and coriander in the nose. Quite smooth to drink. Hops and biscuit in the taste. Bit of malt and hop on the palate. Overall nice but not as hoppy as Id imagined it was going to be.
Tap at Pap.  Pours a dark hazy copper color.  Soapy, floral hop aroma with some caramel malt.  Flavor is slightly sweet and fruity with a nice spicy hop bite.  Decent brew.
Herbal and watery lemon citrus hops notes.    Watery grapefruit juice with a slight touch of caramel.  Good.

Draft at Westside Local. Slightly hazy copper-bronze color with a foamy off-white head and sheet lacing. Surprisingly light aroma of fruity hops. Pretty true to English form with the lighter hop flavor. Pleasant and sessionable.

Herbal and spicy hop nose.  This is a small-scale beer; nothing overwhelms.  Artfully crafted, well-balanced floral, spicy, herbal.  Quick dry finish.  A good dry bitter with nothing wasted.  What a pale ale should be.
Bottle from Cavie.  Hazy orange pour white a nice white head.  Aroma is grassy, a little fruit, and malty.  Taste a little hoppy, a nice malt backbone, and a good bitter finish.  A little thin.

Bottle via trade. Pours a clear copper orange color with a white head. Aroma is dry hops, kinda distant. Leafy notes and a bit of nitrous soil. Flavor is English hops, heavy malts and earthy. Finishes much the same with a lingering hop flavor.

[355ml bottle from Utobeer, Borough Market] Pale amber with a thin white head.  Moderate fizz.  Fresh-tasting,surprisingly little bitterness, mainly caramel with some lemon and pine and earthy malt, easy drinking but less flavoursome than I expected.

Bottle from Uto beer.
Pours hazy amber with a shortlasing head.
Back in the day when I was a hop head I´d probably been rather impressed by this. Unfortunately the bottle was a few months past its bb-date so Im not sure where they intended to go with it.
Bottle.  Golden orange pour.  Citrus, grassy hops, a bit of sweetness, and bread.  Another good selection from Odell.
This is the kind of U.S. beers I like, with that yeasty taste that is so delicious. Very spicy and nice coloured.

Bottle, Beer Ritz, Leeds. Poured a clear bronze colour with a thinnish white head. 
Sweetish nose with some fragrant hop, fruit and candy notes. Lightish body. Sweet malt and citrus hop in the flavour. Dryish bitter finish. Quite drinkable and not without some appealing characteristics.

From Beers of Europe. Oily hops instantly, with caramel aroama and flavour. Spicy bitterness, prickly and grassy on the back of the throat and just a trace of tobacco. Its many things, without being anything definitive, but still high quality. Faintly hazy orangey appearance, with a bubbly white head.

Bottle - Yep, this is what a pale ale should look like: deep amber with a huge foamy off-white head. Lots of herbal hops on the nose with a nice biscuity, crackery malt and a touch of lemony cleaner. Taste is light caramel, without being sweet, herbal hops, and a touch of grassiness on the finish. Nice malt backbone. Light carbonation and pretty full-bodied for what it is. Nice beer.
Tasted on tap at the brewery in Fort Collins, Colorado.  Light pale-orange appearance.  Good English pale ale flavor- mild to medium hop flavor with a good malty body.

12 oz bottle

Thanks to someone for sending me this in a recent trade. I set it aside to open without delay because not only was a light sessionable beer it actually sounded appealing. After two or three offerings from Odell I have a feeling I will be seeking out more. How theyve flown under the radar for so long is really a mystery.

Aroma / Appearance - The mandarin orange body shimmered with life. Mostly foam at first it took a while to settle into something that resembled a beer. Chunks of head, like tan icebergs, remained. Bright melony hops mixed with orange glo and pine sol. Smelling like a freshly waxed hardwood floor it is vibrant and alive.

Flavor / Palate - Slightly resiny orange juice washed across the palate. Balanced with a bias towards the hops it sparkles on the tongue. Mildly bitter in the finish it leaves a mark instead of fading away feebly. If I opened the fridge to find a six pack of these it would not be the worst discovery.

Bottle from Liquor Max in Loveland, CO. Pours hazy light amber with a foamy off-white head. Strong hoppy aroma. Medium body; firm carbonation. Flavor is moderate caramel and strong hop. Seems like quite a melange of hop. Finishes a little florally bitter.

Odell Brewing Company--5 Barrel Pale Ale--2005 12 oz. Bottle.  5.20% ABV.  55 IBUs?  (4.5 / 5.0)  Arctic Liquor Beer of the Month Club Selection June, 2005.  Mild lacy head.  Clear bright thin amber color.  Huge floral hop bouquet.  Zesty crisp dry sweet caramel mild citrus fruit hop biscuit malty body.  Rich clean hop spice balanced end.  Zow!	  Sampled 6/28/2005.

Odell Brewing Company--5 Barrel Pale Ale--2007 12 oz. Bottle.  5.20% ABV.  36 IBUs.  (3.75 / 5.0)  Arctic Liquor Beer of the Month Club Selection January, 2007.  Mild lace thin head.  Slightly BC hazy bright dark gold color.  Floral fruit ester mild hop front.  Mild sweet creamy caramel fruit mild biscuit body.  Smooth mild hop spice mild fruity citrus end.  Too Aged?  Sampled 1/17/2008.

Sampled on 9/10/2010. This American Pale Ale pours a medium orange gold color from a 12oz bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity and sweet, grapefruity hops. A medium bodied American Pale Ale. The malts are fruity and sweet, lots or orange and citrus flavors. The hops are grapefruity and citrusy. Nice carbonation, lively but kind of soft. Nice balance. Mouthfeel is a full and round. Finish is crisp and clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
On tap at KC Yard House.  Clear orange with a medium biege head and some lacing.  Aroma of piney hops and citrus.  Tastes a bit of caramel and hops.  Thought balanced well.  Nice brew.
Had on vacation in Denver, CO during the second night of camping.  Pours a haxy orange with a thin white head that laces well.  Taste is grapefruit and other citrus notes.  Aroma is hops
Very floral and sweet malt aroma.  Copper, frothy white with lacing.  Floral, sweet malt, apple, grass, and mild sour flavour.  Dry finish with mild bitterness (sour).
Good, not great. pours a hazy orange. certainly lots of hops--starts out really well but gets a bit cloying by the end of the beer.

I had this in tandem with the ODells St. Lupulin Extra Pale Ale and I preferred this one.  It had a somewhat soft palate, with a lighter touch of carbonation, a more oily and resinous body, and a more rounded sense of the hops--less bitter in the finish.  Still, it wasnt a beer to rave about, but drinkable.  Bottle.

Draft at the brewery.  Pale orange-yellow pour with lots of bubbles and a white head.  Hoppy aroma with pine and grapefruit notes.  Some earthy grassy hop notes as well.  The grassy hops seem to dominate the flavor.   Bitter earthy flavor.  Pine and citrus are absent.  Decent pale ale.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden beer with a weak offwhite head. The aroma is malt and hops with citrus. The flavor is close to the nose with some additional sweetness. The palate is sweet. Overall an average beer.

Enjoyed at 10,000 feet.  Pours copper clear in my REI cup with a creamy beige head. Fresh nose. Citrus pine hops a pale spicy malt. Citrus lemon flavors.  The malts seem older with a slight caramel. Light bitter alcohol finish. Not bad. 8/4/7/3/14

Bottle.  Bronze beer with a strongish head.  The aroma is sweet and strongly hopped, and the flavour is solidly well hopped with a sweet finish.  Overall a fairly good hopped beer with a light sweet finish.
Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Aroma is malt and peach hop. Flavour is malt, peach, citrus and grapefruit, and a fruity note.

Bottle.  Amber with a fluffy off-white head.  Aromas are toffee and pine with oranges, grapefruit and cream.  Some light melon and kiwi with fruit flavoured tea.  Flavours are sweet toffee malts with resinous green pine, woody and tea dry aspects and a grapefruit/pine bitterness.  Lightly gritty on the palate with prickly pine on the finish.  A good hoppy brew.

Clear, amber/bronze appearance, creamy, bone white layer of foam, good, lasting 1/2 ".

Floral aromatics in the nose, caramel and toffee malt tones, a minor splash of citrus. Bit buttery. Really classic British pale ale feeling. 

Taste: hops up front, nice bitter buzz, not gonna be able to guess what hops are in play, but they have to be British. This bitterness continues on the palate and revisits with every new sip. Tasty, juicy malt, tropical fruit....mmm, I wonder what malts are in here. Scottish? Pineapple and banana, meets caramel and vanilla. 

This a tasty, complex ale, one Im going to have to give some consideration to again and again. Delicious hoppy pale ale, with tasty, tasty malt. Mmmmm.
Bottle @ J.C.G US Tasting, Pt 3. Pours unclear golden with a small white head and lacings. Nose is orange and peachy hops. Medium bodied. Flavor adds a bit of malts. Medium bodied. Tired . .
Tap pours amber with medium head. Aroma is hops and caramel. Taste is the same with mild citrus. Not amazing but drinkable.

From Bottle- Pours a dark copper color with a good head that lasts and good lacing. Clean & fresh aroma with a hint of citrus. Trace of malt and a little citrus. Nice tartness with a bitter finish. Quite refreshing. Smooth & creamy. Moderate body with nice carbonation. A very well balanced brew that is not overpowering. Good for 2-3, well worth a try.
Pours amber, tiny beige head. Aroma is a little lacking, some hops, cardboard.

Bottle from the Cave. Slightly hazy golden colour, off-white head. Aroma is hoppy and fruity, with grapefruit. Flavour is hoppy, sweet lemonade, and some caramel malts. Medium carbonation. Sweet and fruity finish. Well drinkable.
Tap. Semi hazy orange amber pour with a white clingy head. Aroma of hop and bread. Taste is caramel, hop, and mild citrus. Decent.

On tap at the White Horse American Beer Festival, 2nd July 2010. Slightly hazy orange amber with a small white head. Aroma feels very dry with some grain but no obvious hop notes. In the mouth its very dry and bitter with lots of lemon and orange. Rolling it around the mouth brings out a breadiness. Definite bite to the finish.

Aroma of cascade-esque hops, light grapefruit and caramel malts. Appearance is rusty gold with creamy tan head; well carbonated body. Flavor matches the nose. Palate is creamy and finishes slightly lively. A good example of the style.

Keg at The White Horse American beer festival, Parsons Green, London. A copper coloured pour with a slight head. Malty aroma. Tastes malty, fruity, hoppy, caramel, some sweetness. Decent session beer from Odell.

Picked up single 12-oz bottle at Heritage Liquors in Maplewood, MN. Pours a semi-clear golden amber colored brew with an average sized off-white head that leaves behind some spotty lacing and white ring. Aroma of mostly citrus zest, some light caramel malt, and mild grapefruit. Taste is medium bodied, flavors of dark berries, caramel malt, citrus zest hops and a touch of sourdough bread. Finish has a nice balance of sweet malt and sharp Pale Ale bitterness that slowly disappears. A solid American Pale Ale over all.

Pours a hazy orange-amber with a perfect creamy off-white head and great lacing.  Aroma is simple and straightforward, with slightly fermented bread (a la sourdough) and a light spicy hop nose.  Flavor is equally straightforward, with a nice malty backbone and plenty of hop bitterness.  Creamy and oily textures clash a bit and this beer coats the tongue.

Pours a clear copper with a thin layer of frothy cream-colored head. Aroma is earthy bread, fresh cut grass and woody. Flavor is a bit of earthy caramel, hay/bread. Body is light and crisp with active carbonation.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear copper orange with thin bubbly gray head.  Malty aroma of subtle citrus of hops, slight berry, cake.  Medium bodied, citral, hoppy finish, sessionable.  Crisp cakey hops character, spruce, citrus.  A solid pale ale, just what a pale ale should be.

Light amber with a creamy beige head. Aroma of toasted biscuits, mellow herbal and earthy hops. Sweet and malty with some smooth hop bitterness. Medium to light body with a very creamy mouth feel. This is a great easy drinking beer, I could see sessioning the hell out of this.

12 oz. bottle to pint glass. Pour is a honey orange color with a tight froathy head and a sticky lacing. Aroma is lemon and citrus, but a little skunky. Taste is crisp and citrus along with lemon and honey. Palate is medium, crisp and has a dry swallow. I enjoyed this one well. I found it refreashing and well balanced.
For an English Style Pale, this one holds up nicely. The English malts are nicely complimented by the American hopping schedule.
Gold color with a medium head.  Light citrus and biscuity aroma.  Moderately bitter taste right away.  Light orange and caramel notes.  Quite grainy.

12 oz bottle from Princetons.  Pours a golden color with a finger of white head.  Nice floral aroma coming from the  hops with the flavor coming through as more of the same with some nice malty balance.  Slightly hoppy finish.  Very smooth mouthfeel, easy drinking beer.

Bottle pours a translucent amber with golden notes and a medium creamy/bubbly off white head that laced.  Aroma of nice floral and citrus notes and caramel.  Flavor of caramel malt, nice floral and citrus notes.  A really nice hoppy pale ale.

12oz Btl.  Amber Orange, slight head and spotty lacing.  sl, lower carb.  Very nice floral aroma w some citrus plus a nice piney character.  Malt comes thru w sweetness and nuttiness.  Bitterness mellows toward the end with sweet-dry finish.  Sl lingering piney after bitter begs for another sip.  Somewhat diff than other PAs.  Very nice.

On tap at the Groveland Tap. Pours an blondish orange -- good beige head and nice lacing. Earthy hops from this one -- a little musky, some peat, some grass, a bit of dirt. There is a butteriness to the malts that smooth over the hops. Low carbonation enhances the buttery mouth feel. However, the flavor profile is is pretty low - I expected something a bit more robust. The grassiness of the hops comes through on the way down. Not bad, but I wont remember this one.
Pours golden with white head, aroma is grassy, floral hops.  Taste up front is a nice clean, crisp, floral hop, a bit of bready malt but a smooth not bitter finish.  Very nice and drinkable.

12oz bottle.  Pours a pale orange amber color.  Slightly hazy.  Thin white head.  Aroma of caramelized sugars and a big hop citrus.  Heavenly.  A touch of toffee.  Flavor of pale malts, rich caramel.  Finishes with a sharp pine bitterness.  Medium bodied.  A very well tasting APA.   8,4,8,5,14 19 apr 10.   355ml bottle.  Dated04.17.09.  Orange amber color.  Decent lacing.  Aroma of nice citrus, some pine.  Good hop.  Finishes with a heavier hop than malt.  Light-medium bodied.  6,4,6,3,13 14 mar 09

12 fl oz bottle, courtesy of Papsoe. Pours hazy orange with a small off-white head. Aroma is mild fruity, slight grassy and caramelish. Bitter, citrusy, slight grassy and mild herbal. Medium dry malt base, breadish. Bitter and subdued fruity hops finish.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours a hazy amber with a tiny off-white head. Sweet caramel in the nose and some American hops. Medium body, fruit and caramel with a little dry hoppiness. An easy drink. 100410
Pours light amber with a white head. Aroma is citrusy hops. Flavor is floral and citrus hop and a bit of malt.

Pours hazy orange with rocky, egg shell head, dissipating to a 1/4" pillowy mess with good lacing.  Nose of missing hops and carmel goodness.  This is definitely not how its supposed to be, but still pleasant.  Caramel with a slight twinge of butterscotch and chocolate malt, mild bitter and slightly oxidized.  Very balanced, highly drinkable.  I would love to have it fresh.  Solid quaff.
Clear, oakwood color.  Stiff, small head. Sulphury, off aroma.  Peanutty - in a word, peanutty.  Not hyper-hopped.  Medium finish.  Tap, Flying Saucer, Kansas City.

Clear orange, big frothy beige head. Aroma of crisp floral and zesty tropical citrus hops. Taste of sweet hops with a short bitter finish. Body is medium-thin, but thicker than most English pales, with soft carbonation.

Great Pale ale, Copper color is right on for this style, Purchased in bottles and served in mugs.  Pour had 3/8 inch head and great lacing.  Lots of Hops, which is in line with this style although a little much for me.  Carbonation is right on.  Great beer, I will buy again.
Bottle from Utobeer. Hazy amber, smallish head. Grains, ginger bread and lots of citrus. A very well made pale ale, a bit watery, but very drinkable and hoppy.

The girls brought this back with groceries when we were at a family reunion in Colorado. Nice drink between tasting the 17 top 50 beers we had accumulated for the reunion. Takes me back to growing up on the farm with bread rising in a warm oven and the smell of grain a earth seeping in the windows and apples ripening in the sun. A little watery but easy to drink. A bit of citrus at the end adds to the experience. Kind of unexpected quality for something just picked up on a whim.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Golden with lasting flat head and lace.  Mild toasty honey orange aroma.  Mild honey citrus fruit with medium assertive very dry citrus hop finish.  Very clean.  Sessionable.  Perfect mouthfeel for style.  Excellent.

Sample from a bottle at Jonesys Eatbar in Denver. The beer is a pale amber color with a medium thin off-white head that recedes steadily Stringy lacing on the glass. Floral hops aroma with citrusy undertones. Medium body with herbal and floral hops flavors, as well as some citrus and malt. The finish is hoppy up front with a citrusy aftertaste. Decent all around.
pours a dark gold colour with a medium head. aroma is musty bready malt and a floral hop presence. Flavour is medium floral hop over a light malt body.

Bottle. Nose is subdued earthy hops with a little bready malt. Flavor is the bread and biscuit, cut with a nice tart bitterness and floral hop. Good easy drinker, but a little water and just not a lot of very pronouced flavors. Points for the fact that I wnated another one for reasons not readily apparent above.

Bottle.  Pours a clear, orange body with a fine, jiggly, white head.  Laces fairly well.  Sticky, resinous hop aroma of citrus and flowers.  Not as herbal as anticipated from an English PA.  Some bready malt underneath the hops.  Flavor is of light biscuit, sticky pine and resin and a dash of flowers.  Somewhat soapy.  Light-medium body, mild carbonation, moderate bitterness and a touch of lingering resin.  Overall pretty decent.

Bottle from Big J.  Clear orange body, lacing clear-white head.  Nose is delicious, of musty hops with cookie dough and light caramel in the Stone strong ale tradition.  Taste is bitter with a touch of sourish citrus and a touch of resin.  Medium body with a lasting sort of cola aftertaste (again, citric acid?).  Very good nose, but taste has no more character or distinctiveness than the similar-tasting Amber Bock.

Pours a medium amber, and quite appealing too. Generous rocky meringue head. Dissipates after a few minutes but is quite spectacular at first. Bravo!

Nose is a clean, soapy note that is actually good. Ivory soap? A hint of vanilla and green apples.

Very smooth body, smooth taste. Everything meshes well - seamless. Slightly high carbonation, moderate malt, moderate hop bite, and a vanilla w/slight creaminess is there. Finishes with hop tartness and a mildly syrupy sweetness. Overall very good for an everyday beer.

12oz bottle and on tap.  Pours a clear, light copper color with a one finger head and leaves a decent bit of lacing.  Aroma is floral and citrusy hops with some earthy malts.  Tast ha a fairly heavy biscuity and earthy malt flavors, but is well balanced with a crisp hoppy citrus finish. Very slight bitterness in the aftertaste.  Light to medium bodied amd very smooth easy drinker.

Pours an amber almost orange color with a pretty decent head. Smells a big hoppy with a little bit of a floral undertone. The taste of the beer is a little underwhelming. It is a little bitter with a slight hoppy taste, but the flavor is pretty light. The beer goes down pretty easily with many small bubbles. This isnt the best pale ale Ive had, but it goes down easy and is relatively refreshing.
Draft at Bacaro Restaurant in Boulder. Hazy orange with little head. Fruity sweetness in aroma which is continued in its also floral hop. No bitter bight.

Pours a see through brown/amber color with a small white head. Lots of carbonation, and good lacing. Aroma is light floral/citrus hops and malt. The taste has a very small amount of sweetness, a very small amount of bitterness, and a good deal of water. Im not a big fan, nothing really stands out and theres not enough complexity and flavor.

12oz bottle 8/22/09-Pours a slightly hazy amber with a small off white head. Aroma of hops, malt, and sweetness. Taste is of the same with a bit more sweetness thrown in. This medium bodied brew is not bad but I am not a fan of this style. Nice brew otherwise.

12 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a very slight hazy amber color with a one finger thick off white head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is herbal and pine hops.  Flavor is much of the same along with some light toasted malt sweetness.  Medium body.  Nice finish.  A nice beer.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2011 A grandiose thanks goes out to mtoast for this special brew and for the locale! Had the pleasure of sampling this at the 7/9/2009 Pittsburgh RB tasting extravaganza (PGHRBEXT) at the Sharp Edge Creekhouse, again courtesy of mtost. It will be a long time, if ever I see a spread of bottles like I did there. I am not good enough for the beers that were that we served! For example, how about this beer;  5 barrel pale ale!  Pale lager appearance, no visible carbonation. Typical light yeasty beer aroma. Taste is a little odd and brash. Has many ale attributes fer sure. I think I detect a little leather on the palate. Finish is fairly light, not bad overall!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours a lightly hazy copper, with a substantial, soapy lace - nice aromatic hop nose (peppery, herbal), sitting on top of a bready malt base - the flavor has a peppery hop kick up front, followed by some semi-dry, crackery maltiness - gets a little herbal and almost minty near the end - quite refreshing and tasty - an underrated pale.

This poured a yellow/amber color with a white head. Aroma was slighlt spicey hops, pale malts, and not much else to be honest. Flavor was uch more bitter than I would have expected form an english pale ale. Nice mixture of what seemed like british and american hops

Had this one at the Pittsburgh RB tasting.  Thanks guys.  Ill take this time to express my thanks for all the great stuff we had at the lineup there, as most of you are rating these in the same order that I am, so I wont repeat myself.  This one appears to be over the hill.  Smell is a high point with hoppy goodness, but its all downhill from there.  Appearance and palate are average at best, and the taste is just off, which is a letdown.  Full Disclosure:  I dont like my pales to be this spicy.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a bright orange-amber color with a small white head. The aroma was sweet, tangy and lightly peppery with a fruity hop undertone. The flavor was spicy, tangy and fairly full of fruity hops with a lingering nutty malt base and a peppery finish. Solid.

I remember being impressed by this beer when it first came out. Its orange with a nice head and looks great in a pint glass. Smells good but I can see why this is "English" style. This is a nice balanced pale ale. Its very easy to drink, tasty, I can drink several of these, I should have bought a twelve-pack.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-10-2007 03:23:49

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2010 Amber with a lasting white head. Malty aroma with a pine note. Sweet malty flavour with pine hop flavour but not enough bitterness 6-3-5-3-11
2010 re-rate: Noted some peach hops and better bitterness
Drank at Brasil Brau 2009. Golden color with a nice white head, aroma is hopy kind of herbal. Flvor is a pleasure with some citrus notes. Mouthfeel is bitter. Good beer!
A good balanced pale ale. Not too hoppy and a nice caramel flavor. I pick this up when the store is out of the Odell IPA.
Draught. Pours a light amber with a medium size white head. Aroma of sweet caramel and citrusy hops. Flavor is of sweet malts and light on the hops. Decent pale ale, but not my favorite.

12oz bottle from Fox and Hound in Lone Tree, CO. Pours orange with white head. Aroma is floral hops, citrus, and caramel malts. Flavor is balanced between hops, citrus and caramel malt. Nice solid pale ale.

Pours with a clear, amber-orange body topped by a medium to thick head with some lacing.  Its sweet and malty with a slight grassy hoppiness and a good balance.  Medium bodied, smooth and a touch dry.
Pours a clear honey amber. Aroma is floral and pine tree.  lightly sweet initial taste with a floral hops and a slight bitter bite to finish.

Bottle pours clear amber with an insignificant, thin white head. The nose is well balanced, showing notes of toasted malt, caramel, floral hops, and a tiny bit of soap.  The initial flavor starts off sweet, followed by a body of citrus and caramel, with a dry, slightly bitter finish.
Has a lot of hoppy flavor, it has good body good flavor.  Overall a pretty good beer from Odell

Bottle. Pours a clear amber color with a small white head. Has a malty hoppy aroma with some hints of caramel. Sweetish malty fruity hoppy flavor with some hints of caramel. Has a sweetishfruity malty hoppy finish.

Bottle. Moderate roasted note for the malt, moderate to heavy smell of herbs, light soap for the yeast, and hints of apple, vinegar and metal. Head is small, wispy, off-white, with fair lacing and good legs and is almost fully diminishing. Flavor starts out moderately bitter, acidic and acetic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is light to medium, watery, with a lively carbonation and has a dry finish. This English Pale Ale could use a little sweetness, but the herb-like hop aroma is quite unique.

12oz bottle. Good floral aroma. Copper body with good white head and decent amount of lace left on pint glass. A sweet plae caramel malt in flavor and some what watered down. Best before end of month so this one may of lost its zip.

Fairly typical pale ale in apperance. Nose is a little metalic. Not over-carb as some reviews suggest. Taste tetters along the lines of English Pales, with a lean to the American hop side. Some U.K. bready profiles flirting with a dry finish. I like the finish alot on this one, in fact. Dry and hoppy.

I have found my taste for Pale Ales comming back home. American IPAs almost ruined anything less for me. Time to get back to basics for a while. Enjoy!

Other than the IPA, I think odell is terrible, but Ill rate this one..looks like rusty urine, too roasty and dry, almost tastes like a wheat...thin and bland...no thank you
Bottled. Pours golden color with a medium beige head. Aromas of grapefruit and berry. Flavors are similar with a crisp hoppiness. Its decent but not good.

Im confused.  Maybe my six pack somehow bypassed the hops process.  This beer was as unobjectionable as it is unremarkable.  Surprising, since I loved their IPA.  Keep a six of this on hand to satisfy your mainstream beer friends and impress them with your knowledge of micro brews.  Other than that, pass.

Appearance: Pours a clear, burnished gold body with a frothy, modest-sized, white head.

Smell: Spicy, citrusy hop nose with a backing of toasted (though only lightly, mind you) malts and just a thin sliver of caramel.

Taste: Fine, lightly grainy malts with a restrained sweetness upfront. Spicy hops along with a pinch of bright lemon zest accompany a medium bitterness. A dry caramel taste perks up on the other side of the bitterness. Finishes dry, crisp, and with just a little, lasting bit of hop bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-plus carbonation.

Drinkability: Pleasant and exceedingly drinkable while providing ample flavor all the while. Recommended, provided you dig light pale ales.
clean fresh hop aroma with perfume  and peach.  orange under a small white head.  peachy hop flavors.  nice simple pale ale.
(Bottle). Light orange color, with an medium off white head with moderate lacing.  Light hop aroma.  Hop taste with earthy flavor on the finish.  Also has a light bitterness. Moderate carbonation.
Tap, I was pleasantly surprisedwith this one and the amount of hops in it, usually you cant go wrong with that.  It also had some caramel backbone.  Highly carbonated, but just slightly thin.

Pours a light light copper with big head.  Dissapates with decent lacing.  No real aroma noted, just a slight astingency.  Flavor is fine, but fairly muted.  I guess I just dont appreciate an old standard pale anymore.  Not bad, just nothing there.

on tap at papago...

pours a darker hazy copper color than the ipa with a similar head... fluffy, soapy and white with lots of clingy lace. 

the aroma is of very soapy british style hoppiness... mixed in are a fruitiness of some sort, orange, flowers, caramel and soft earthy spices. 

the flavor is a nice blend of the aroma characteristics... with a spicy dry finish and a dryness which continues to parch the mouth into the aftertaste. lots o hops in this one! so much so that the mouth feel is prickly from them! medium bodied with a nice sessionable mouth feel...7/4/7/3/15/3.6

14 karat pour produces a fluffy white head and minimal lacing.  Aroma is of lemongrass, caramel, and resin.  Flavor follows with a lingering bitterness that sticks to the palate after the sip.  Not bad but nothing about this beer makes me want to buy another.

On tap at Falling Rock in Denver. Pours a clear amber with a big white head. Light aroma, of hops, citrus, and malt. Taste is a blend of hops and malt, both sweet and bitter. Lingering light bitterness. Decent.

12oz bottle. Pours a crystal clear light orange body with a small, white, quickly disappearing head that leaves decent lacing. Aroma of creamy caramel malts and sweet pine resin hops. Flavor is pretty standard, but has a decent amount of sharp hop bite that carries throughout. Light bodied and fairly well balanced. Smooth drinking and a nice piney aftertaste. Overall, nothing out of the ordinary, but a really good drinking pale ale with a decent bitter backing.
pretty average pale ale, not much complexity, straight forward and simple. slightly better than fat tire
Pours a nice amber with a white head. Aroma is hops, citrus and caramel. Flavor is hops, citrus, pine, caramel, malt. Decent Pale Ale.
Draft at Brewery Aug 08:  Poured a amber color with a thin white head.  The aroma was citrus and hops.  The taste is sweet, grassy, hoppy, and a bitter aftertaste.  Overall, a tasty brew.

Bottle.  Pours a clear amber with a 2 finger off-white head that results in nice lacing.  The nose is caramel and light citrus hops.  Taste is caramel, bread and light hops with a semi-bitter finish.  Medium mouth feel.  Decent pale.

Bottle.  Pours clear amber-golden, with a big two finger head, good lingering lacing.  Very fruity aroma of apple, fig and caramel.  Medium-thin, crisp body.  Malty apple caramel up front.  Pine resiny and grapefruit hop flavors pick up at the end, with a satisfyingly bitter aftertaste.
Bottle courtesy of aplusbreaks.  Pours copper with a nice white head.  Smells of earthy and dry.  Tastes Tastes sweet and lightly spicy with a peppry finish.

Bottle 355ml.Clear medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, wood, yeasty fruit, yeasty spicy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (050808)

12oz bottle. cloudy orange color. pours with little head. lots of lemony hop aroma, classic english malts are present as well. the abundance of hops give this beer a lush juicy citric taste. great bitterness. a solid, simple american pale ale.
Had this at a restaurant in my hometown.  I was really impressed.  I usually dont care for many pale ales but this one was good.  Nice hoppy, malty taste.  Would definitely drink again.
On tap, ESPN Zone Denver. Nice balance of sweet caramel malt and fruity crisp hop character (orange zest, passionfruit).
